body:
I might have a look at this if I have the time, also if you are doing some passes over the harvesters then go over the "got stuck in the refinary because everyone is clustering around me" bug if you have the time.

Its quite game breaking atm :/
@WolfGaming since #7618 (now merged) there shouldn't be any blockings. Harvs are laid out in the field till a refinery is freed.

Sorry just read that, been out of the loop for a while.
Great that its fixed but we should have a look at fixing this later without doing that hack :)

I just noticed that this could be improved further. When you select a position for harvesting, first it performs a move activity, then "find resources" activity. This could be optimized. I'll work on it.

I've changed the way harvesters find their resources. They now always try to find a resource available which is the closest to their refinery. This should make harvesters resource collection way more efficient.

I will look for ways to improve performance, but I'd like some feedback about how do you feel the new behaviour of harvesters,
If I order harvesters to mine a far away patch of resources they stop moving. I have to manually move them near to the patch I want them to mine before they will move when ordered.
@RoosterDragon problem solved. It will now search also further locations. Previously it would not.

I have no idea how feasible that is in this particular case, I'm just throwing in the idea. Maybe caching the various trait look-ups of `FindResources`, `HarvestResource` and `DeliverResources` in the constructor instead of in the Tick might help performance a little as well?

@reaperrr then I should pass an Actor in the constructor and alter all calls to find resources to pass that param. It's ok to do so and try how it impacts performance. I should develop some unit tests to try it, but before doing that #7565 should be accepted and merged (where I introduce those changes which would allow me to microbenchmark) and test.

this is pure AI-improvement ... they work like Ants now ! more people should give it a test ... 

some problems ... : 
1. harvester pretty much ignore "given orders" by the player and immediately choose a new ore-tile by themself neglecting the manually assigned work-order ... flexibility is gone 
   this makes it hard to avoid the next issue : 
2. harvesting the closest orefield isnt always a good decision ... as you can see in the next screenshot ... (harvesters own choice , without my interfering) ... a better alternative here would to acutally work on 1 line and not switch between the lines until the harvester is full ...  
   (i have made this particular map with ore-lines to explain the problem) 

![orelines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6651840/3b4d83c8-ca57-11e4-9109-b9aa39cabe33.png)

@MicroJOo I've just changed it to go to the resource spot closest to the harvester instead of the ore ref, I also felt it like you said. Please fetch and reset again.

Regarding about clicking, and ignore given order, it doesn't really ignore orders. It's just that the default search area from a click is 12 tiles radius. That's quite big but I didn't change it. Could you please try again and see how it feels with 12 tiles radius? I could try to reduce that search radius if you say I should.

yes , the harvester now take the closest ore-tile ... so thats not a issue anymore ... 

the more common standard gameplay ( or what i consider as standard ) ... 1-4 harvesters each refinery ( 1-10 harvesters for every player per game) ... works pretty good 

---

and then i did some tests under more harsh conditions for them... like 20 havesters and only 2 refinerys and then afterwards flooding my base with refinerys ,  i have noticed a couple of weird but rare things happening  .. 
- here a block ... (edit: even saw it happening with only 4 harvesters ingame)

![blocking](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6652715/74866bf2-ca78-11e4-8548-197d2ecf75f3.png)

~~some of the harvesters tried a alternative route to reach their closest ore-tiles~~
*probably because the path was blocked ... 
- they start waiting (or just lollygaging , idk ) for a none-occupied refinery although their not even full 
  (this happend particular when 20 harvesters work for 2 refinerys) 

![thinking](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6652092/3c34ea3c-ca62-11e4-871f-a383abf2d50f.png)
- on top of that ... ive noticed "lag spikes" here  resulting in a choppy gameplay

![lagspikes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6652722/f316a1a8-ca78-11e4-8885-3d2021f2126f.png)
- [red alert] harvester for bots are broken , they stop 1 cell before reaching the ore , and do nothing

Wow that's really a comprehensive testing! Good job @MicroJOo.

I'm aware of bots. It seems they have different logic on resource harvesting and will require further work, yet it would be cool if someone also interested in working with this teams up with me, as this is quite complex.

Maybe I should start by refactoring the harvesters area of code like I did with pathfinder and Mobile.

About lag spikes, I was certain they were going to happen when testing, don't ask me why. When deciding for the closest resource, the harvester has to analyze 24x24 cells aprox, which is quite big. Multiply that for as many harvesters there are and for each time I go for a resource, and you have a performance bottleneck indeed. I need to come up with an heuristic to take this kind of decisions faster.

About those weird routes they took, I should see in live in which conditions, where you clicked, initial harvester position, linked refinery, etc. I should add some logging to the code to debug this in addition to some tests.

the weird route was probably just because the direct path was blocked at the time ... happend only once... wouldnt take that all too serious because of 20 harvesters/2 refs

regarding the lag-spikes , the situation got more relaxed once i had more refinerys ...

There's though one thing that should be made clear un order to proceed adequately with this implementation, and this is a question to the developers and players: how do you wish harvesters should move when finding resources? How do you wish they should behave when delivering resources? How should they react under several circumstances like blockings, etc...?

If we can enumerate and list them we will have made a good work towards the implementation and reality.

a thing that i noticed when i tried gods divide ... 
you probably want harvesters to prefer "rich" cells over cells with peanuts on it ... and even sacrifice time (path) for it ... on great divide theres "ore mines" under the gems , once theyre done with the gems around the mines ... they will start harvesting the "regrowing" ore (when its closer to them) ... 

![harvester logic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6652859/5960d366-ca7e-11e4-97d0-d43f069307e0.png)
That would be cool and a real challenge to develop :)

I think I have an idea for a specific implementation for this.

If we want to maximize our resource harvesting efficiency, we should consider each resource patch from our position, and give them a score based on distance and value of the patch. Based on this, we choose the one with the highest score and go for it. We could implement this with a priority queue.

Does it sound cool?

indeed , that sounds awesome

---

we do need more people to test this , specially for cnc and d2k
another improvement would be , to let them avoid "mines" as long as there is a alternative path to the next ressources

I've come up with a variation of the harvester pathfinding that is waaaaay faster and more performant than before and behaves quite in the same way of taking the closest resource that leads to the target. It still needs improvements in terms of scoring and search area, but I would like to know how it feels now, because if people is happy with the way harvesters behave now (still need to fix bots though), this PR could be merged.

Amazing!
Just did a small comparison between this and bleed on a small map (Forest Path), highest FindResources time went down from ~18ms to ~2ms, and at least in that short test i didn't notice any regression in behavior (if anything, subjectively I'd say harvesters don't get stuck/idle as much as they used to).

Off-topic: If you can come up with something remotely comparable for Move/AttackMoveActivity, the biggest path-finding hiccups would be solved.

@reaperrr I could give it a shot, just let me land on it :).

@MicroJOo bots work now. Have to test it though.
i want to do further tests (in red alert) this night , so just give it a bit more time to cook

okay @Rydra ... sorry i still have to bug you with his , but ... :

in our current release , our harvester definitely harvest the tile im ordering them to harvest ... which means ...-> i click on a ore-tile .... and regardless of the distance 1 cell or 100 cells... he definitely harvest what im telling him to harvest

in your patch this doesnt work ... or just with the trick to click on a "empty" cell near the ore/gem tile you want him to harvest ... then he will start searching from there

what this means basicly is ... if you have a circle full of ore ... and inside is a patch of gems ... then theres no way a harvester will harvest this gems first (he will disobey if you order him to do that , and instead going for the "closest" rich cell ... if the ore around is closer to him (and this is alway the case when he is jumping of the ref after reloading )

this "disobey"-behaviour  is pretty much a regression

---

other then that , im really happy with the autonomous behaiviour when i dont have my eyes on them ! cant say a lot about the faster pathfinding and more performance because i need a couple of actually living and breathing human people to test this with .... so this would be a :+1:+musthave for the next playtest ! ... after the disobey-regression is fixed

bots work of course now

@MicroJOo it's not really a regression, it's actually the way I programmed them to do. They go on a straight line on the path you determined and if a resorce tile is found in the way, they pick it. There's still no "collecting efficiency" going on. That is way we need a consensus about how do they should work:

Should they go immediately for the tile you explicitly click in?

Should they just consider the place where you click in a "search area" and then let the harv do his own and collect what it considers?

All this kind of stuff must be discussed and clearly defined. I'll come up with a proposal of a checklist for this.

Personal preference: When given an explicit target (target a tile with resources) then it must first harvest that specific tile. Thereafter/Otherwise:
Location clicked (an tile that doesn't have resources) is considered a general search area.
Otherwise:
Finds resources to harvest as how an idle harvester should.

@UberWaffe the problem of a "Location clicked is considfered a search area" is that it's different a "Move" activity than a "Harvest" activity. Sometimes I may require a move without triggering resource finding.

Other than that, my proposed behaviour checklist is the following:
- When given a explicitly clicked target that contains a resource, collect that resource
- This is a point of discussion: given a location that has no resource (and therefore we must run a search) should the harvester collect the closest resource to ITSELF that is inside his search radius, or collect the closest resource to THE CLICKED SEARCH POINT (and therefore it will collect resources in circles)? From a personal point of view, I prefer the harvester to collect resources in circles from the point where you clicked (I think this is the way games like Age of Empires work, once a specified resource is depleted they go for the closest one to the "epicenter" (the central point of a search).

Which leads to another discussion: Should the "epicenter" move depending on the latest harvested location? Right now it does.

> Sometimes I may require a move without triggering resource finding.

Hold alt to when clicking to force a move order instead of harvest.

I agree with @MicroJOo and @UberWaffe that explicit orders _must_ be obeyed.  Another case where this is important is if a player wants to harvest a specific cell to clear enough space to place a structure.

> Which leads to another discussion: Should the "epicenter" move depending on the latest harvested location? Right now it does.

This can lead to some strange harvesting patterns.  It would be better if it harvested around the target area until it runs out of resources.

I've changed the current harvesting pattern to go in circles from the last explicitly ordered position, and taking the closest node to the harvester between the center of the search and the closest node from the last harvested resource. To my taste it now presents a quite interesting behaviour, while "obeying" to collect the explictly selected tile as it's been requested.

I would wish to know if you like it better the way it is right now (except for that center search area detail).
